This report was prepared by J. M. Ferreira, principal regional cooperation specialist, Greater 
Mekong Subregion, Mekong Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the 12th Ministerial Conference of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Economic 
Cooperation Program in September 2003, the ministers of the six participating countries—
Cambodia, People’s Republic of China (PRC), Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, 
Thailand, and Viet Nam—reiterated their commitment to pursue a shared vision of growth, 
equity, and prosperity. They also acknowledged that the socioeconomic environment in the 
subregion had changed significantly since the GMS Program started in 1992. The GMS is now 
more dynamic and progressive, with increased economic cooperation among the participating 
countries.  However,  issues  and  challenges  have  also  multiplied,  requiring  even  greater 
cohesiveness and cooperation among the countries if they are to reap the full benefits of 
regional integration and succeed in an increasingly globalized environment.  
 
2.  The  ministers  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  provide  continuing 
support to the GMS Program to attain these goals. The ministers specified that the support 
should focus on coordinating, harmonizing, and consolidating the various GMS initiatives and 
activities  as  well  as  mobilizing  the  corresponding  intellectual  and  financial  resources.  The 
technical assistance (TA) will enable ADB to respond to this request for the subregion.1 This TA 
will allow ADB to not only support the GMS regional cooperation initiative as but also to facilitate 
interaction among GMS Program stakeholders. The TA will provide the means by which ADB 
can link all GMS Program initiatives and activities together and to address strategic issues. The 
TA  takes  into  account  corresponding  concerns  raised  in  the  GMS  strategy  and  program 
documents.2 
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND ISSUES 
 
3.  The vision of a dynamic and prosperous GMS, with a population substantially free from 
poverty,  can  be  best  pursued  through  a  well-thought-out  strategy  and  the  corresponding 
implementation of a carefully crafted program. ADB’s support for the GMS Program since 1992 
has  greatly  helped  achieve  coherence  and  momentum  in  the  GMS  regional  cooperation 
initiative. The support framework must be continued. The Program was assessed in an impact 
evaluation study conducted in 1999–2000.3 The study’s findings have been taken into account 
in the preparation of this TA paper. 
 
4.  The  key  objective  of  the  GMS  Program  is  to  reduce  poverty  through  enhanced 
connectivity,  increased  competitiveness,  and  a  greater  sense  of  community.  Many  GMS 
projects have focused on infrastructure development, aimed at increasing physical connectivity 
among the member countries. Reform and harmonization of policies and regulations have been 
increasingly  emphasized,  as  has  the  enhancement  of  institutional  and  human  resource 
capacities  required  to  fully  realize  the  benefits  of  such  connectivity,  and  thus  improve 
competitiveness. Programs are also being pursued to address key subregional environment and 
health concerns, thereby increasing the awareness of the degree of interdependence in the 
subregion and the importance of promoting a greater sense of community. Concerns regarding 
the  impact  of  infrastructure  development  and  enhanced  physical  connectivity  on  the

5.  Much has been accomplished in the last decade in the broad areas of cooperation under 
the GMS Program. A significant level of physical connectivity has been achieved, with most 
basic transport routes already completed or under construction. In power development and 
trade, several projects are either already operational or on-stream. The GMS countries have 
also reached broad agreement on various areas of economic exchange, such as facilitating 
cross-border transport of goods and people, and promoting regional power trade.  
 
6.  In terms of environmental protection and preservation, the GMS countries have laid the 
foundation for a Strategic Environment Framework to guide investment decisions in critical 
sectors and areas, and to mitigate potentially adverse effects of economic development on the 
environment. As interrelated poverty and environmental concerns arise from development of the 
areas along the Mekong, an integrated basin-wide approach to such development underpins 
natural resources management in the GMS Program, emphasizing the protection of livelihoods 
and prudent management of natural resources. Initiatives to strengthen human resources have 
been  undertaken,  such  as  the  implementation  of  the  Phnom  Penh  Plan  for  Development 
Management4 and the mitigation of the cross-border spread of communicable diseases. 
 
7.  While  broad  agreements  have  been  forged  and  substantial  progress  in  physical 
connectivity  has  been  made,  the  GMS  ministers  requested  accelerating  the  pace  of 
cooperation.  This  implies  increasing  the  pace  of  implementation  of  the  various  initiatives, 
improving  the  policy  environment,  and  operationalizing  agreements.  Among  the  major 
commitments  of  the  GMS  leaders  at  the  first  GMS  Summit  in  November  2002  were  the 
completion of the transport corridors and their development into economic corridors, with the 
accelerated implementation of software arrangements for infrastructure linkages, including the 
possible  introduction  of  a  GMS  visa;  acceleration  of  energy  development,  including  the 
implementation of the Intergovernmental Agreement on Regional Power Trade; and formulation 
of an action plan on trade and investment facilitation. To deepen cooperation and flesh out the 
implementation aspects of the various initiatives, substantial work will be needed at all levels 
within the GMS framework, including sector working groups (SWGs), senior officials’ meetings 
(SOMs), ministerial meetings (MMs), and summit meetings.  
 
8.  At the 12th Ministerial Conference in Dali, PRC, in September 2003, the GMS ministers 
emphasized the importance of expanding the dialogue with all GMS stakeholders. The ministers 
called  for  stronger  involvement  of  development  partners,  not  just  by  providing  financial 
resources,  but  also  by  sharing  their  development  experience  in  the  region.  The  GMS 
governments requested ADB to help mobilize strategic development partners and to ensure that 
the resulting assistance is well coordinated. 
 
9.  Filling the major resource gap between the funding requirements to achieve the goals of 
the  GMS  Program  and  the  amounts  available  from  ADB  as  well  as  other  bilateral  and 
multilateral development agencies has become a priority. Intensifying resource mobilization has, 
therefore, become imperative, and the impact and leverage of development assistance that 
ADB can provide should be maximized. Concurrently, recent economic reforms and the sound 
economic growth of countries in the subregion have led to the gradual expansion of the local

business sector and growing interest of foreign investors, thus opening new possibilities for 
private sector participation and financing in the GMS Program.  
 
10.  Recent developments point to new challenges. The setting for regional cooperation has 
changed significantly since the GMS Program started. Region-wide health concerns such as 
Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome and avian flu or new international security threats require 
timely and innovative responses or a recalibration of existing initiatives. As the facilitator/catalyst 
for the GMS Program, ADB must be able to provide quick but carefully considered, sound 
guidance on these matters. The various mechanisms and forums of the GMS Program must be 
sufficiently innovative and flexible, providing effective venues for focused discussion of the 
issues and for formulation of timely solutions, thereby enabling the GMS countries to respond to 
these threats and challenges in a coordinated manner. 
 
11.  The  GMS  Program  has  achieved  its  success  through  forums  and  mechanisms  to 
exchange ideas and agree on joint action. Now that the GMS Program has to address new 
needs,  issues,  and  challenges,  these  forums,  mechanisms,  and  instruments  require 
strengthening and streamlining to bring GMS efforts to the next level—that of more intensive 
implementation and operationalization. As the requirements of the GMS Program and, hence, 
the focus of the TA through its various phases, evolved, so has the role of ADB in the GMS 
Program. Starting with a simple role of major provider of financial and technical assistance, ADB 
now  plays  multiple  roles  in  the  GMS  Program,  such  as  the  main  development  partner 
coordinating  other  activities  of  other  external  funding  agency  in  the  region,  and  a  broker 
devising and using means to balance relationships among the member countries. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
  
A.   Purpose and Output 
 
12.  The TA’s overall goal is to enhance cooperation among the GMS countries in addressing 
key regional issues to achieve their shared vision of growth, equity, and prosperity in the 
subregion. Its purposes are to (i) provide essential support for the GMS Program and strengthen 
its role as a key agent of regional cooperation, within the framework of the GMS Regional 
Cooperation Strategy and Program; and (ii) sustain and accelerate the momentum of the GMS 
Program.  Attaining  these  purposes  will  require  strengthening  the  role  and  operational 
effectiveness of the GMS Summit, MMs, SOMs, and SWGs in pursuing the thrusts of the GMS 
Program. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
13.  The TA will have the following outputs: 
(i)  increased capacity of GMS governments in preparing and implementing GMS 
Program activities through hands-on learning by the GMS national secretariats 
and concerned units of line agencies in member countries, 
(ii)  enhanced capability of the GMS Program to respond quickly to new demands 
and unforeseen problems and challenges, 
(iii)  increased involvement of stakeholders in the design and implementation of GMS 
initiatives, 
(iv)  increased resource mobilization for the GMS Flagship Programs, and  
(v)  improved  information  dissemination  and  awareness  of  the  GMS  Program’s 
strategic orientation and flagship initiatives.

4    
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  Strengthening the Role of Various Forums. The work plans of the SWGs, SOMs, and 
MMs will be linked more closely to the GMS strategic thrusts and priority flagship programs. 
Particular attention will be paid to further structuring the SOMs and SWGs and ensuring regular 
consultations. Refining sector strategies, prioritizing and programming projects and activities, 
resolving issues, and formulating action plans for adoption by the MMs, will remain a constant 
objective  at  the  SWG  and  SOM  levels.  ADB  will  regularly  and  closely  monitor  the 
implementation of flagship programs, in consultation with the national secretariats and GMS 
units of line agencies of member countries. The capacities of these secretariats and units are 
thus being strengthened with ADB assistance.5 The output of the various GMS forums will be 
enhanced by the increased participation of development partners and the private sector. The 
work of these forums will be dovetailed to ensure that key issues are addressed in the lead-up 
to the GMS Summit of Leaders in 2005. 
 
15.   Enhancing  Capacity  to  Respond  to  New  Demands,  Unforeseen  Issues,  and 
Challenges. To be able to effectively and promptly address specific new demands that, based 
on recent experience, have arisen in the subregion, capability needs to be built within the GMS 
Program to undertake quick, problem-specific, and policy-focused studies at the request of the 
GMS member countries. This can be done by providing for the engagement of experts on a 
needs basis to quickly assess the problems, in coordination with local GMS authorities and ADB 
resident missions, and propose a coordinated response acceptable to the GMS countries and 
ADB. The deliverables will be in the form of brief issue-specific and results-oriented reports and 
action plans.  
 
16.  Increasing  Involvement  of  Civil  Society  and  Stakeholders  in  the  Design  and 
Implementation  of  GMS  Initiatives.  Channels  will  be  expanded  for  consulting  with  and 
obtaining inputs from community-based organizations and nongovernment organizations on 
major  GMS  initiatives.  The  output  of  these  engagements  will  be  used  to  enrich  and,  if 
necessary, reorient the work of the various GMS mechanisms and forums so that they provide 
highly effective guidance and inputs for the GMS Program.  
 
17.  Increasing Financial Resource Mobilization for the GMS Flagship Programs. Given 
the continuing large financial resource requirements of GMS projects and activities, resource 
mobilization will be further intensified in consultation with the GMS countries. Projects with 
substantial needs and prospects for cofinancing from development partners will be identified. 
The development matrix will be used as an important tool in these efforts. 
  
18.  Improving Information Dissemination and Awareness of the GMS Program. This 
component will aim to generate a greater awareness and commitment to the GMS Program and 
its activities among stakeholders and various target groups. New media instruments will be 
tapped for this purpose, in consultation with the Office of External Relations, such as making the 
development  matrix  accessible  via  the  Internet,  developing  new  GMS  publications,  and 
preparing and promoting articles on the GMS Program for use by various media. The style and 
content of the GMS Web page will also be improved.

19.  Strengthening the various GMS forums (para. 14) and thrusts and activities (paras. 15–
18) will be undertaken with the assistance of the TA consultants and utilizing the various 
mechanisms  and  instruments  under  the  GMS  Program.  In  undertaking  the  activities  and 
measures  to  improve  the  effectiveness  of  the  various  GMS  forums,  the  consultants  and 
concerned ADB staff will work in close coordination with and active involvement of the national 
secretariats and agencies concerned, so that the latter can in the process also enhance their 
skills  and  knowledge.  Within  ADB,  the  Mekong  Department  will  ensure  strengthened 
coordination and cooperation with the Office of Cofinancing Operations, Office of External 
Relations, Private Sector Operations Department, and Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.25 million equivalent, comprising a foreign exchange 
component of $1.00 million and a local currency component of $250,000 equivalent. The foreign 
currency component will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The 
participating GMS governments will provide the remaining $250,000 equivalent in kind, including 
the  contributions  for  hosting  the  GMS  Summit,  MM,  SOM,  and  SWG  meetings.  The  cost 
estimates and financing plan for the TA are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  ADB will be responsible for implementing and monitoring the TA in consultation with the 
GMS governments. GMS national coordinators will continue to serve as the focal point for 
coordinating subregional activities in each member country. 
 
22.  The TA will finance about 80 person-months—26 international and 54 domestic—of 
consultancy  services.  A  core  group  of  consultants  will  provide  advisory,  technical,  and 
administrative support services to assist in the overall management of the GMS Program. 
Consultants for private sector development and for communications and media affairs as well as 
short-term consultants to address specific demands will also be engaged. The consultants will 
all be hired as individuals. They will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The consultants’ outline terms 
of reference are in Appendix 3. 
 
23.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months, from August 2004 to July 2005. 
 
IV.   THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Strengthening the Greater Mekong Subregion Economic Cooperation Program and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of individual consultants will be engaged to provide advisory and technical 
services and assist in capacity-building activities of the technical assistance (TA). A total of 26 
person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and  54  person-months  of  domestic 
consulting services will be required. The consultants will report to the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  task  manager  for  the  Project.  The  indicative  person-month  allocation  and  terms  of 
reference are set out below. 
 
A.  Core Group Consultants 
 
1.  Regional Cooperation Economist (international consultant, 12 person-months) 
 
2.  The responsibilities will be as follows: 
 
(i)  Identify  opportunities  and  support  activities  to  promote  public  sector  (e.g., 
international development agencies) participation in Greater Mekong Subregion 
(GMS) flagship programs. 
 
(ii)  Provide inputs to activities to increase private sector participation in GMS flagship 
programs. 
 
(iii)  Provide inputs to the formulation of the GMS Regional Cooperation Strategy and 
Program (RCSP) and its updates.  
 
(iv)  Help counterpart national secretariats prepare resource papers, in consultation with 
concerned  ADB  divisions,  for  GMS  ministerial  conferences,  meetings  of  GMS 
forums and/or working groups, and other GMS-related events. 
 
(v)  Participate in consultation and monitoring missions to the GMS countries. 
 
(vi)  Oversee improvements in the style and content of the GMS Web site, provide 
inputs  to  it,  and  help  formulate  and  implement  the  GMS  publications  and 
information program.  
 
(vii)  Monitor the development matrix, help update it together with concerned ADB sector 
divisions, and recommend improvements in its use for planning and programming 
and resource mobilization for the GMS Program. 
 
(viii)  Provide the required documentation of substantive preparations for various GMS 
working groups and other activities for easy future reference by counterpart GMS 
national secretariats and concerned ADB staff. 
 
(ix)  Backstop joint activities with other regional cooperation initiatives. 
 
2.  Regional Development Economists (2 domestic consultants, 24 person-months 
combined)
